Award.AwardTitle: Doped-nanocrystal/graphene hybrid structure for noble metal-free photocatalytic hydrogen production

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
In typical semiconductor-based photocatalysis to produce hydrogen, noble metal co-catalysts, typically Pt or Pd, are often used to enhance the efficiency of charge carrier separation and transfer that are essential for the function of catalyst. This noble metal component makes the economics of the overall system untenable. Many approaches have been investigated to reduce the dependence on noble metals. In this award from the National Science Foundation Catalysis & Biocatalysis Program, Profs. Dong Hee Son and Hae-Kwon Jeong of Texas A&M University propose a new and more economical strategy based on unique material combinations and properties. The proposed research aims to greatly enhance hydrogen production efficiency of semiconductor-based photocatalysts by exploring the synergistic effect of transition metal doping of the semiconductor catalyst combined with the formation of a hybrid structure with reduced graphene oxide (RGO). The role played by the costly noble metal co-catalyst will be replaced by abundant transition metal dopant ions (e.g., Mn or Cu), which were recently shown to extend the electron lifetime in semiconductors and thus enhancing the efficiency of charge separation and transfer. The combination of the doped nanocrystals with RGO offers the advantage of a more efficient photocatalytic reduction reaction, facilitated by the RGO functioning as the large-area electrode. The investigative team will develop the correlation of the structure of nanocrystal/RGO hybrid photocatalysts with the efficiencies of key steps of photocatalytic reduction (i.e., charge separation, charge transfer) and the overall hydrogen production efficiency, leading to an optimized structure of the catalyst for hydrogen production.


The educational component of the proposed research will focus on the development of experiments for undergraduate research as a part of training the participants in a NSF-REU program and in undergraduate research classes. These experiences will lead to the development of a transportable experiment kit that will be used on site at local high schools, with training of local high school teachers through a RET Program. This will be designed as a new component of the university-wide outreach effort, exploiting the dissemination mechanisms that are already in place at Texas A&M.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, we investigate the strategy to enhance the photocatalytic H2 production from water with noble-metal free photocatalyst based on the Mn-doped quantum dots producing highly reactive electrons with large energy content, i.e., hot electrons, which are combined with the reduced graphene oxide (RGO) that will efficiently harvest hot electrons for H2 production.

In the first project year, we synthesized the composite structure of Mn-doped quantum dots (QDs) and reduced graphene oxide (RGO) with varying sp2 carbon contents and measured the effect of RGO on the energy transfer process in the composite structure. This study was performed to understand the effectiveness of the synergistic effect between Mn-doped QD, the source of hot electron, and RGO that collects the electron. the photocatalyst. We found a strong dependence of the effectiveness of the Mn-doped QD/RGO composite structure as the photocatalyst on the degree of sp2 hybridization, which is important in optimization of the chemical structure of the catalyst.

In the second project year, we performed a comparative study that can highlight the benefits of hot electrons in enhancing the photocatalytic H2 production. We indirectly confirmed the production of hot electron from Mn-doped QDs via biphotonic ‘upconversion’ process we hypothesized in our earlier by examining the quadratic dependence of H2 production efficiency on the excitation light intensity. We also demonstrated that hot electrons exhibit much higher photocatalytic activity in H2 production from water than usual lower-energy electrons from typical semiconductor photocatalyst as anticipated.

In the final year of the project, we made a direct observation of the hot electron by measuring the current produced by hot electrons. We also confirmed that the hot electrons with large energy can travel much further distance than the lower-energy electrons, which has a great potential to increase the spatial extent of photocatalytic reaction, and that some of the hot electrons can acquire energy sufficient to go above the ionization threshold.

Modified by: Dong Son

    Hot electron-induced photocatalysis
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: In this project, we investigate the strategy to enhance the photocatalytic H2 production from water with noble-metal free photocatalyst based on the Mn-doped quantum dots producing highly reactive electrons with large energy content, i.e., hot electrons, which are combined with the reduced graphene oxide (RGO) that will efficiently harvest hot electrons for H2 production. In the first project year, we synthesized the composite structure of Mn-doped quantum dots (QDs) and reduced graphene oxide (RGO) with varying sp2 carbon contents and measured the effect of RGO on the energy transfer process in the composite structure. This study was performed to understand the effectiveness of the synergistic effect between Mn-doped QD, the source of hot electron, and RGO that collects the electron. the photocatalyst. We found a strong dependence of the effectiveness of the Mn-doped QD/RGO composite structure as the photocatalyst on the degree of sp2 hybridization, which is important in optimization of the chemical structure of the catalyst. In the second project year, we performed a comparative study that can highlight the benefits of hot electrons in enhancing the photocatalytic H2 production. We indirectly confirmed the production of hot electron from Mn-doped QDs via biphotonic ?upconversion? process we hypothesized in our earlier by examining the quadratic dependence of H2 production efficiency on the excitation light intensity. We also demonstrated that hot electrons exhibit much higher photocatalytic activity in H2 production from water than usual lower-energy electrons from typical semiconductor photocatalyst as anticipated. In the final year of the project, we made a direct observation of the hot electron by measuring the current produced by hot electrons. We also confirmed that the hot electrons with large energy can travel much further distance than the lower-energy electrons, which has a great potential to increase the spatial extent of photocatalytic reaction, and that some of the hot electrons can acquire energy sufficient to go above the ionization threshold.
